posts.content:
"Joshua Declares 'I’m a Warrior' After Dubois Defeat: Future in Boxing Uncertain"


Anthony Joshua vowed to keep fighting despite suffering a devastating fifth-round knockout against IBF heavyweight champion Daniel Dubois at Wembley, marking the fourth loss of his career. This defeat eliminates his chance to become the undisputed world champion, raising serious questions about his future in the ring.


In an all-British showdown, Joshua was knocked down four times as Dubois unleashed a relentless assault. Despite the setback in front of a record-breaking crowd of over 98,000, the former Olympic champion expressed his determination to continue his boxing career.


“Of course I want to continue fighting,” Joshua said, highlighting his resilience. “We rolled the dice for the third time... Fine margins will cost you at the top level.”


Promoter Eddie Hearn remains optimistic, suggesting a potential rematch with Dubois or an all-British clash with Tyson Fury could be on the horizon. “2025 is going to be an interesting year for Anthony Joshua... he will definitely be back,” Hearn stated, emphasizing that fans can expect entertaining bouts ahead.


"Dubois Eyes Undisputed Title After Shocking Victory Over Joshua"


Daniel Dubois, 27, is now focused on his path to becoming the undisputed heavyweight champion after his stunning victory over Anthony Joshua. Following the fight, he dismissed critics who predicted he would lose, stating, “They were all saying I was going to get knocked out, but we all saw who got knocked out. I did the business and I’m glad I proved everyone wrong.”


As Dubois awaits the outcome of Oleksandr Usyk’s rematch with Tyson Fury, he has his sights set on avenging his previous defeat against Usyk. “This is just the start of my journey. I want to get my rematch against Usyk and put that wrong right,” he declared, emphasizing his ambition to claim the heavyweight division's titles.


SOURCE: CHANNELTV
posts.title: Resilient Joshua Promises Comeback After Dubois Defeat

posts.content:
The event will bring together global leaders to discuss various international issues and policies.


In a statement issued by Stanley Nkwocha, Senior Special Assistant to the President on Media & Communications (Office of The Vice President), Vice President Kashim Shettima departed for the United States on Sunday to attend the 79th UN General Assembly (UNGA) at the directive of President Bola Tinubu. President Tinubu tasked Shettima with leading the Nigerian delegation to the high-level global forum while he remains focused on addressing pressing domestic issues, including the recent flood disaster in Nigeria.


During the 79th UNGA session, Vice President Shettima will deliver Nigeria’s national statement, participate in key meetings, and hold bilateral discussions.


The high-level General Debate, themed "Leaving no One Behind: Acting Together for the Advancement of Peace, Sustainable Development, and Human Dignity," will take place from September 24 to 28, 2024.


SOURCE: CHANNELTV.COM
posts.title: Vice President Kashim Shettima has departed Abuja for the United States to attend the 79th United Nations General Assembly (UNGA)

posts.content:
Results from two more local government areas are expected later in the day.


Monday Okpebholo, the All Progressives Congress (APC) candidate, has taken the lead in the Edo State governorship election.


Okpebholo leads by over 48,000 votes ahead of his closest rival, Asue Ighodalo of the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), in the Edo Central senatorial race. Of the 16 local government areas declared at the INEC Collation Centre in Benin City, Okpebholo has won 10 with 244,549 votes, while Ighodalo has 195,954 votes and has won six local government councils. Labour Party's Olumide Akpata trails with 13,346 votes. After announcing these results, the collation was paused for a recess called by the Returning Officer, Faruk Adamu Kuta, at 2:19 pm.


The break was called to allow time for the arrival of results from two remaining local government areas. The collation center will reopen by 5 pm when the winner of the governorship election is expected to be announced. The collation process began shortly before noon in Benin City, following the election in the South-South state.


The Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) is protesting the election results, alleging irregularities. During a press conference led by Adamawa State Governor Umaru Fintiri, PDP candidate Asue Ighodalo expressed concerns about inconsistencies in the election process. Ighodalo warned that the election might be remembered as the "worst" in the country’s history due to the issues raised.


Members of the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) are protesting in Benin City, claiming that the election results being collated do not reflect the will of the people. They argue that the official results differ from what the party’s agents recorded during the election.


The All Progressives Congress (APC) has urged caution, asking Nigerians to wait for the official election results from the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC). The party emphasized that INEC is the only authorized body to collate results at the ward, local government, and state levels, and to officially declare the election outcome. APC called on the public to disregard any claims of misrepresentation and await INEC’s final verdict.


he All Progressives Congress (APC) also accused Governor Godwin Obaseki of trying to interfere with the electoral process following his visit to INEC’s collation center. The party suggested that Obaseki's actions were an attempt to subvert the election results.


SOURCE: CHANNELTV.COM
posts.title: Edo Gov: APC's Okpebholo leads Ighodalo with 48,000 votes after result from 16 LGAs
